Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Online Consortium of Pacific Northwest Herbaria expanded to Include Taxonomically Diverse Specimens from Large and Small Regional Collections
Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of our project is to digitize (i.e., image and database) botanical research specimens at nearly twenty university, college, and federal agency herbaria in Idaho, Montana, Oregon, and Washington. Vascular plant, moss, lichen, and fungal specimens will be included in the project. Once digitized, we will place these records online for the public through an existing Web portal (http://www.pnwherbaria.org). We are leveraging the cyberinfrastructure (e.g., Ethernet, servers, technical staff) available at several large universities to build partnerships with smaller institutions that otherwise would not have the resources to undertake this activity.

Our project provides tangible benefits to the general public, undergraduate students, and the research community. Digitizing specimens and making them available online creates public access to collections that have been assembled in part through prior federal funding. The specimen data will be downloadable from the Web site, so anyone can use the information to pursue unique interests and questions. Undergraduate students will be involved extensively with imaging and data basing activities, providing them with skills and training applicable to future professional pursuits. Online availability of nearly 2 million Pacific Northwest herbarium specimens will increase access and efficiency for the research community using these collections.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As a result of this NSF-funded project to Montana State University, 55,000 plant specimens housed in the Montana State University Herbarium and that document the native and exotic plant diversity in the State of Montana have been imaged and databased. Two students at Montana State University, both women, were intimately involved in this project, which included an education and training component.

The information associated with these imaged specimens is publicly available through website of the Consortium of Pacific Northwest Herbaria, www.pnwherbaria.org, which is housed at the Burke Museum of the University of Washington, Seattle. Anyone interested in plant identification, geographic distributions, ecological data, and other plant information can access this website. The information can be accessed by filling in relevant fields with appropriate text, or by highlighting a particular region on a map for which plant diversity in that area is desired. The resulting nformation can be returned and organized in several different ways, for example, by taxonomic classification or geographical region (including sorting by state and county). Images of plant specimens are also available, and these include 55,000 images of plant specimens housed at the Montana State University Herbarium. The Pacific Northwest region of North America now has a clearing house for detailed plant information that will serve land managers and any other individuals interested in issues related to plant diversity in this region.
